title: Open Data in Practice Day 1 - Practical Publication
displayTitle: Open Data in Practice Day 1 - Practical Publication
body: This introductory course aims to get you up to speed with latest developments in open data and its significance. It is designed to enable anyone to get started with discovering and using open data and understand the skills and processes required to make it work for you and your organisation.

title: Course overview
body: The first day is split into three key sessions. The first session explores definitions of open data and key characteristics, the second takes a closer look at data publishing platforms and the last will get participants hands-on with publication.

_items.title: Characteristics of data
_items.body:
The session explores key definitions of open data.

The session also examines types of data to determine their uses.

_items.title: Datat discovery patterns
_items.body:
The session explores key definitions of open data.

The session also examines types of data to determine their uses.

_items.title: Publishing platforms
_items.body: Open data is still a developing field and those working within it will encounter a number of common problems. This sessions presents and clarifys the main challenges before examining the future of open data.

_items.title: Hands-on publishing
_items.body:
This session begins by looking at how open licences are there to protect data publishers, while also unlocking value. We show how to build a machine readable open license that can be applied to any online content.

The session then continues by looking at the technical, legal, social and practical requirements for making different types of open data usable and some of the most relevant guidelines to support this process.

title: What is open data?
body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data becomes useable through being available in a common, machine-readable format.

Open data must be licensed. This licence must permit people to use the data in any way they want, including transforming, combining and sharing it with others, even commercially.

title: Challenges of Open Data and Future Developments
displayTitle: Challenges of Open Data and Future Developments

title: Challenges of Open Data
body: Open data is still a developing field and faces a number of key challenges which need to be addressed. The following section outlines some of the key areas
instruction: Click below to explore each of the tools to unlock data that is on the web.

_items.title: Inconsistent definitions
_items.body:
Like any new field, open data needs a strong definition to give clarity around what it is and what you can do with it. While many definitions of open data currently exist, promoted by different organisations and meeting different needs, there is no consistency about the terms used in these definitions.

A recent study by GovLab has highlighted the number of different terms used when defining open data in a simple chart that illustrates the need for greater consistency.

_items.title: Lack of proper licences
_items.body:
The majority of datasets described as 'open' still do not have an appropriate licence to protect the ability of everyone to access, use and share them. As of 2015, only around 46% of data in open data catalogues across the European Union is truly openly licensed.

In the EU, copyright and database laws are complex. While data might be intended to be open, a licence provides legal clarity for users.

The OpenDataMonitor platform provides information and statistics on European open data catalogues.

_items.title: Failure to update consistently
_items.body: Simply publishing a dataset is not enough to ensure reuse and relaise the benefits of open data. Datasets also need to be updated at regular intervals to ensure they remain relevant and up-to-date. However, the vast majority of datasets are not updated consistently as shown by the graphics in this study by Thomas Levine.

_items.alt: Confusion between Open, Big and Personal Data
_items.title: Confusion between Open, Big and Personal Data
_items.body: The open data doamin is closely related to the concepts of 'big data' and 'personal data', leading to the terms sometimes being used incorrectly to describe each other. While open data describes what you can do with a dataset (namely access, use and share it), big data is a vendor-driven term used to describe the size of a dataset. finally personal data refers to any data which concerns individuals. It is possible for big data to be open, for personal data to be big and for open data to be personal but all three terms refer to very different things about a dataset. Using these terms correctly and understanding when data is open, big or personal is a key challenge to the understanding of the open data field.

title: Marques of quality
body:
Marques of quality provide users with confidence about the quality and usability of open data.

There are two key indicators of open data quality:

_items.title: 5 Stars
_items.body:
The '5 Stars of linked open data' include the basic legal definition and technical excellence of the published data.

The 5 Stars were developed by inventor of the Web, Sir Tim Berners-Lee, in 2001. The 5 Stars make recommendations for the format and structure of the data.

You can learn more about the 5 Stars in modules 10 and 13 of this course.

_items.title: ODI Open Data Certificates
_items.body:
The Open Data Institute's Open Data Certificates are practical, social, legal and technical guidelines to consider when publishing or using open data.

The certificates act as a self-assessment questionnaire for publishers, and in some cases users, to assess and benchmark the full usability of a dataset.
Take me to the ODI Open Data Certificates site

title: What do ODI Certificates look for?
displayTitle: What do ODI Certificates look for?
body: Community-driven standards define the legal, practical, technical and social requirements for an open dataset to be useful.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Legal requirements
_items.body:
In addition to the open licence, there are three legal requirements that need to be considered. You must:

  • Protect sensitive information like personal data.
  • Preserve the rights of data owners.
  • Promote correct use of the data.

_items.title: Practical requirements
_items.body:
It is important that open data can be found and relied upon by users.

This means that open data publishers must:

  • Link to the data from their website.
  • Update the data regularly if it changes.
  • Commit to continue to make the data available.

_items.title: Technical requirements
_items.body:
There are three recommendations that define the technical aspects of open data:

  • The format in which the data is published.
  • The structure of the data.
  • The channels through which the data is available.

_items.title: Social requirements
_items.body:
For data use to be sustainable, it is important to have an engaged community of users. The best datasets have:

  • Active support channels.
  • Discussion groups and forums.
  • Published how-to guides on working with the data.

title: Common data structures
body: Not all data can be appropriately expressed as a spreadsheet. Different file formats may have to be considered. There are three key structures to be aware of: tabular, hierarchical and network.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more

_items.title: Tabular
_items.body:
The most common structure for data is tabular. Data is organised into rows and columns listing sequential values, such as expenditure.

If the data is based on separate entries that are not linked to each other then a tabular file structure in a format such as CSV is ideal. An example of appropriate tabular data is the Italian data portal’s museum attendance figures.
Take me to Italian Data Portal

_items.title: Hierarchical
_items.body:
Hierarchical data shows the relationships between data points, such as a family tree or municipalities in each country. If the dataset depends on the relationship between data points and follows a structure in which data points are linked in vertical ‘trees’, a hierarchical data structure in a format such as JSON is ideal. An example of appropriate hierarchical data is this JSON file from json.org
Take me to the json.org example

_items.title: Network
_items.body:
Network structured data allows relationships to exist between any combination of elements in any direction.

A good example of a network data structure are social networks. Think of your network of friends and their friends on Facebook; consider first, second and third degree contacts on LinkedIn.

The web is another example of a network data structure, where web pages link to any number of other pages in any direction.

title: Finding open data in the right formats
displayTitle: Finding open data in the right formats
body:
As a user of open data, it is important to understand how publishers are delivering different formats to you for reuse.

Not all data is suitable for download either because it is too large, too regularly updated or too complex to expose as static files. Some data may need to be split into smaller parts. Other data may need to be published as live feeds to make sure it stays up to date.

_items.title: Downloadable open data
_items.body:
Tabular data is the most suited for download. This is why most government open data portals are predominantly tabular data. However managing millions of rows of data may require other considerations:

  • Should the data be split into smaller datasets?
  • How often should the data be updated?
  • How will changes in the way you publish affect the previous releases?

_items.title: Live data and data feeds
_items.body:
Some data is not suitable to be made available as a downloadable file.

Much of this data is updated so regularly that the file downloads would be too large for most users. This type of open data structure may be made available by a machine interface, also know as an API.

There are many services that make machine interfaces available over the web. These services can be directly integrated into other web applications. For an example of an open data API, look at the Belgian railway company.
Take me to iRail API

title: How to find hidden data
body:
From data we gain information, from information we gain knowledge and insight.

Please note that just because you can extract hidden data, it does not make this data open. You should always check the terms of use and licences of the website before gathering or using data for any purpose. For further details on licensing, please refer back to module 4 of this course.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Extension downloads
_items.body:
Some websites have been built to offer a way to extract data by adding an extension to the URL of the web page you are viewing. For such websites, usually maintained by organisations who also publish downloadable open data, adding the correct extension will trigger a download of that page in a data format, as opposed to a browser format.

A good example of this is the UK Government website (gov.uk) which provides any page in a data format simply by adding the relevant extension like “.json”, for example www.gov.uk/browse/business.json.

Try it with the UK Trade data by viewing the following page and then adding “.json” to get the data.
Take me to the UK gov trade tariff

To view the data in a more human readable form copy it into jsonlint.io

_items.title: Data feeds
_items.body:
Many websites provide links to data syndication feeds that can be subscribed to.

These feeds may be RSS feeds, Twitter alert feeds or other less common types. Feeds can be used to get raw data about a broad selection of content.

For an example of a raw data feed, look at the BBC news feed in XML.
Why not try out the news feeds from the BBC in XML.

Now you can use a free online tool to make that data easier to use
Go to codebeautify and enter the BBC feed URL under 'Load URL'

or get alerts for flooding from your nearest river (UK only).
Take me to river level guages

_items.title: Source code
_items.body:
Going beyond providing a simple route to data, many sites have data embedded in the web page's source code.

Why not check out the ODI's experimental 'Hidden Data Extractor' tool to find source code?

Take me to ODI Hidden Data Extractor

_items.title: APIs or machine-readable interfaces
_items.body:
Some websites or web services will expose a machine-readable interface, or API, for querying and accessing their data.

Examples of services that have APIs include: Open Corporates (open), OpenSteetMap (open), Twitter (not completely open), Flickr (some content open), LinkedIn (not open).

Most of these services use a web based API and allow addition of extensions (try “.json” on OpenCorporates). Although this API looks the same as the earlier example in this section, it's formal status as an API provides a guarantee that the service will be available.

_items.title: Scraping the web
_items.body:
If none of these techniques work, you may need to scrape the human-readable web pages. While this can be reliable you have the added risk of the layout changing as well as the content.

Why not try out magic.import.io to see how easy it can be?

title: Getting started with Data Cleaning
body:
Data cleaning is essential to ensure that when the data is used, the right conclusions are made.

Often errors are not even noticed by data publishers because the data can change over many years. In other cases, errors can be the result of human mistakes in data entry, like mistyping or incorrect abbreviations.

Be aware that cleaning may take longer than you think. A careful cleaning process will, however, save substantial time in the long-run.

Follow our data cleaning exercise to get started with Open Refine and discover how easy it is for yourself.

Get started with data cleaning in Open Refine

Below you can find the datasets used in the OpenRefine exercise

  • Dataset 1: Louisiana Secretary of State Officials
  • Dataset 2: Projects Dataset
  • Dataset 3: UK GP Earnings

title: Open Data in a Day
body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data is a raw material for the digital age but, unlike coal, timber or diamonds, it can be used by anyone and everyone at the same time.

Any restrictions imposed on the use of open data will limit its use in creating new value.

Open data can bring diverse benefits to governments, businesses and individuals. It has the power to improve services, grow economies and save our planet.

Open data needs to be properly licensed in order to ensure the broadest possible use. The data should also try to follow as cloesly as possible the best practices available to support publication and reuse

Want to take your open data journey further? The ODI offers a full range of courses to support those working with open data at our
